Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploratory role of microRNA-induced dysregulation of FOXO and Sirt1 in aging muscles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Boriek, Aladin M.
Proposal Number: 1451619

The proposed studies explore the effects of mechanical stretch on intracellular signaling pathways that protect from oxidative stress and address how these pathways are affected by aging. Data generated in the course of the proposed project have the potential to uncover, for the first time, the involvement of specific intracellular regulatory molecules in the function of anti-oxidative pathways in the aging respiratory pump. The proposed studies are expected to provide novel insights into understanding the functional impairment of respiratory muscles and potentially guide interventional strategies for slowing aging.

The overall goal of this early stage developmental research project is to investigate how mechanotransduction is disrupted in aging muscles of the ventilatory pump and whether microRNAs play an important regulatory role in this process. The following specific aims are proposed. 1. To explore mechanisms responsible for loss of mechanosensitivity of signaling pathways regulating Sirt1 in old skeletal muscles of the diaphragms. 2. To explore possible dysregulation of specific mechanosensitive Sirt1 targets in the aging muscles of the ventilatory pump. 3. To explore a potential role of a particular microRNA, miR-200c, in the regulation of FOXO and Sirt1 in aging muscles of the ventilatory pump. Results from this developmental research project could provide for the first time new fundamental information on the novel signaling role of specific microRNAs in the regulation of the anti-aging gene, Sirt1. In addition, the proposed studies are likely to uncover new mechanisms that are responsible for the dysregulation of mechanosensing signaling pathways, and could spur further signal mechanotransduction work on the aging cardiac and smooth muscles. Hence, the proposed studies may generate information that could potentially contribute to guide interventional approaches for slowing aging. The investigators will attract undergraduates through Baylor College of Medicine SMART Program that supports under-represented students to pursue research careers initially as undergraduates. The investigators will continue to work with the graduate students in molecular physiology at Baylor College of Medicine. The proposed project will provide a working model of a successful integration of education and research training for strengthening the ongoing multidisciplinary collaboration between molecular physiology and cell biology at Baylor College of Medicine. Additionally, the PI plans the development of a new graduate course, and to continue his outreach activities with the Iman Academy High School students in the Houston area and with the Michael DeBakey Museum at Baylor College of Medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this two-year EAGER application was to explore whether microRNAs are involved in the mechanical regulation of the anti-aging gene, silent information regulator 1 (Sirt1) and their potential role in modulating oxidative stress and inflammation in the aging respiratory muscles. Regarding Intellectual Merit of our project, our studies provided novel insight to improve our understanding of the mechanisms underlying an underappreciated aging consequence: A ventilatory functional impairment.  Our data provided novel signaling role of specific regulatory genes, microRNAs in the regulation of Sirt1.  Our findings have the potential to transform the field of signal transduction by providing, for the first time, the potential to uncover innovative signaling role of specific microRNAs in the regulation of the antiaging gene Sirt1.  In addition, our data are likely to uncover new mechanisms that are responsible for the dysregulation of mechanosensing signaling pathway, and should spur further signal mechanotransduction work on the aging cardiac and aging smooth muscles. Our studies tested the idea of mechanical regulation of Sirt1 in the skeletal muscles of the diaphragm, and we made progress towards uncovering whether the titin is involved in modulating the mechanosensing signaling pathways in the diaphragm. It is important to recognize that Sirt1 is a critically important gene in skeletal muscle physiology. Our published work outlining an interaction between EGR1 and SIRT1 describes an autoregulatory loop that shuts down the stretch-induced Sirt1 expression would be critically important in the field of mechanotransduction in skeletal muscle. In addition, our recent discovery of the identification of differentially regulated mechanomiRs and their predicted target genes and associated biological pathways is quite exciting. We found that mechanomiRs from the let-7 family members, especially let-7e-5p and miR-98–5p, were highly dysregulated in the diaphragm of a titin-mutated mouse, an animal model of muscle weakness. Another important and critical contribution of this exploratory grant was identification of miR-434-3p as a highly downregulated miRNA in the skeletal muscle of aging mice. We found that miR-434-3p play a role in protecting myocytes from apoptosis through eIF5A1. Our data uncovered a role of MicroRNA-434-3p in the regulation of age-related apoptosis through eIF5A1 in the diaphragm.

 Regarding broader impact of our project, the proposed project provided a working model of a successful integration of education and research training for strengthening the ongoing multidisciplinary collaboration between molecular physiology and cell biology at Baylor College of Medicine. We have been committed to train underrepresented minority students. For example, Mary Adyeye, an undergraduate student, who was supported by an NIH Short term training grant that is designed to increase diversity.  Ms. Adyeye is an African American who was at the junior level at the Albany University. She invested the summer of 2016 in the PI’s laboratory.  In addition, she attended a daily seminar that was offered by investigators at Baylor College of Medicine.   She was instrumental in analyzing complex physiologic data on the differential contribution of costal and crural muscles to the volume displacement of the diaphragm.  She presented her work in the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students of 2016. Furthermore, she earned a co-authorship on a published paper in the Am. J of Physiology. Mary Adeyeye is now an MD/PhD student at the University of Texas Medical School.  Our project yielded multiple exciting papers in traditional rigorously-reviewed scientific journals.
